summary: This is a sealed transcript of a conference before Chief District Judge Colleen McMahon regarding a grand jury subpoena in the Southern District of New York. The government attorney explains that the investigation into the subject (implicitly Jeffrey Epstein) opened in late November/early December 2018 and that the U.S. Attorney's Office had contacted the law firm Boies Schiller, among others, as part of identifying victims and witnesses. The judge grants the government's request related to the subpoena.

persons.name: Colleen McMahon
persons.context: Presiding judge over the conference regarding the grand jury subpoena. She questions the government about contacts with the Boies Schiller firm prior to the subpoena's issuance.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Listed as the United States Attorney in the appearances section of the transcript.

events.title: Investigation Opened (Possible Date)
events.description: The government attorney states the investigation was opened on either Friday, November 30, or Monday, December 3.

events.title: Investigation Opened (Possible Date)
events.description: The government attorney states the investigation was opened on either Friday, November 30, or Monday, December 3.

events.title: Court Conference on Grand Jury Subpoena
events.description: A sealed conference before Judge McMahon where the government explains the timeline of its investigation and its contacts with victim/witness counsel, leading to the judge granting the government's request.

keyFacts: The document is a sealed transcript of a court conference regarding a grand jury subpoena, indicating active investigative proceedings.
The government investigation into the subject (contextually, Jeffrey Epstein) opened in late November or early December 2018.
The U.S. Attorney's Office contacted the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner early in the investigation as they were identified as representing victims or witnesses.
Judge McMahon references wanting to avoid a 'Chemical Bank kind of situation,' likely alluding to a precedent concerning improper contacts or procedures.
The judge grants the government's request related to the subpoena after being satisfied with the explanation of pre-subpoena contacts.
